section.title: Future Continuous and Future Perfect
section.sectiontitle: Use the Future Continuous to talk about something in progress at a definite time in the future. Use will or won't + be + present participle to make statements.
section.text1a: I'll be watching the football between 7.30 and 9.00.
section.text2a: He won't be using the computer in the evening.
section.sectiontitle2: We can use the Future Continuous to ask about someone's plans, especially if you want something or you want them to do something.
section.text3a: I'd like to borrow the car. Will you be using it on Saturday?
section.text4a: Will you be coming past my house? There's something I'd like to show you.

section.title: Future Continuous and Future Perfect
section.sectiontitle: Use the Future Perfect to talk about something which will be completed before a definite time in the future. Use will or won't + have + past participle.
section.text1a: By the time this trip is over, I'll have been to twelve different countries.
section.text2a: She won't have finished her essay by Friday.
section.sectiontitle2: We often use the Future Perfect with time phrases with by: e.g. by that time, by this time next week, by tomorrow, by then, by the end of the trip, etc.
section.text3a: I'll have taken the test by this time next week.
section.text4a: Will you have used up all your money by the end of the trip?
